video.title: How to Pass Tier 1 & 2 Selections - Part 2/3: Tier 2 Selections
video.description:
Part 2 of my 3-part series on passing Tier 1 and Tier 2 selections in U.S. Special Operations.

Today we’re breaking down how to pass Tier 2 selections—for pipelines like Navy SEALs BUD/S, Army Ranger Assessment and Selection (RASP), Army Special Forces Selection (SFAS), MARSOC/Force Recon, and AFSOC JTAC/TACP selection.

What’s different about Tier 2 selection?
Tier 2 selections lean heavily on team events and deliberate stress. You will get yelled at. You will be tested in your ability to function under extreme physical and mental pressure—especially as a teammate. They're actively trying to make you quit.


---

Here are my 3 key tips for passing Tier 2 selections:

✅ 1. Show Up Fit—and the Right Kind of Fit
Don’t just be gym-fit. Be selection-fit. You need to move weight over distance. Rucking is the great equalizer—train to the point you can run with a ruck. Lift weights so you know how to move load efficiently. Once the ruck is on, the clock doesn’t stop, and nobody cares about your excuses.


---

✅ 2. Don’t Be a Tool—Be a Teammate
Always be reliable. Never be late. Always have the right gear. Help your team without making it about you. They’re looking for teammates—not prima donnas, not lone-wolf superstars. Remember: you can get peered out if your team doesn’t want to work with you.


---

✅ 3. Never Quit—Embrace the Misery
These selections are designed to make you want to quit. Don’t avoid discomfort in training—seek it out so you’re ready for it. Embrace the misery. Stay positive no matter what. Master your self-talk. Don’t let your mind turn on you. Know exactly why you’re there—and make sure you’re doing it for you.


---

If you're serious about making it through selection, remember: it’s not about being the toughest guy in the gym—it’s about being the most dependable, resilient, and unbreakable when everything goes to hell.

👉 Check out Part 1 of this series where I break down the differences between Tier 1 and Tier 2 units. And stay tuned for Part 3, where we’ll talk about how to pass Tier 1 selection.
